metadata./Keywords: Secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma; Posterior synechiae of the iris; 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy; Macular hole; Face-down position; Case report
metadata./Title: Secondary acute angle closure glaucoma after 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy for a macular hole: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Posterior synechiae of the iris rarely cause secondary angle-closure glaucoma after pars plana vitrectomy, mainly reported in cases with high postoperative inflammation. The face-down position with gas tamponade 
can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma in phakic eyes owing to relative pupillary block. This report presents a rare 
case of pseudophakic eye with secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma after 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy 
and long-term vitreous gas tamponade for a macular hole.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 61-year-old Japanese female patient presented with a chief complaint of right-sided visual 
impairment that had persisted for several months. Slit-lamp examination revealed deep anterior chamber and moder ate nuclear sclerotic cataracts in both eyes. The axial length of the eye was 23.53 mm right eye and 24.05 mm left eye, 
and the fundus examination revealed a full-thickness macular hole (stage 3) in the right eye. The patient underwent 
simultaneous cataract surgery and pars plana vitrectomy with 7-mm diameter 3-piece monofocal intraocular lens 
implantation, internal limiting membrane peeling, and air tamponade. There were no complications during surgery. 
Due to non-closure of the macular hole, a second pars plana vitrectomy with internal limiting membrane inverted 
flap and SF6 gas tamponade was performed 13 days later. The patient maintained face-down position after both sur geries, and 6 days after the second surgery, intraocular pressure was elevated to 53 mmHg, and acute angle-closure 
glaucoma with iris bombe was diagnosed in the right eye. A laser peripheral iridotomy was performed, resulting 
in a deepened anterior chamber, normalized intraocular pressure, and a closed macular hole.
Conclusions This case presents a rare occurrence of secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma in a pseudophakic eye 
after 25-gauge minimally invasive pars plana vitrectomy and SF6 gas tamponade for macular hole. The cause was pre sumed to be posterior synechiae of the iris or relative pupillary block due to forward pushing of the intracapsular 
intraocular lens by vitreous gas. In cases where surgery is repeated without achieving macular hole closure, necessitating long-term face-down position, where vitreous gas is retained for an extended period, or when a large-diameter 
intraocular lens is implanted, secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma should be considered. This applies even 
when the 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy is performed not for a highly invasive proliferative diabetic retinopathy 
but for macular hole repair, especially if the patient has a pseudophakic eye.
Keywords  Secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma, Posterior synechiae of the iris, 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy, 
Macular hole, Face-down position, Case reportOpen Access

Page 2 of 6 Takahashi et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:501 
Background
With the advent of 25- and 27-gauge microinvasive 
vitrectomy systems [1 ], combining phacoemulsifica tion and vitreoretinal surgery has become a common 
approach for treating vitreoretinal diseases [2 ]. Among 
the various complications of vitrectomy, postoperative 
posterior synechiae of the iris (PSI) is reported to occur 
at a frequency of 7–30% [3 –6]. Although PSI rarely 
causes secondary angle-closure glaucoma, it has been 
recently reported following combined phacovitrectomy 
[7, 8]. However, most cases occur in patients with sig nificant postoperative inflammation, such as those with 
proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) [7 , 8].
Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with internal limit ing membrane peeling and gas tamponade is also an 
important surgical technique to close the macular hole 
(MH) [9 ]. After surgery, patients often adopt a facedown position (FDP), allowing gas bubbles to press 
against the MH to facilitate its closure [10]; however, 
this position can, though very rarely, cause postopera tive complications such as acute angle-closure glau coma (AACG) [11] due to relative pupillary block from 
anterior lens movement, especially in phakic eyes.
Herein, we report a rare case of secondary AACG in 
a pseudophakic eye following 25-gauge PPV and sulfur 
hexafluoride (SF6) gas tamponade for MH. The cause 
of AACG was presumed to be PSI or relative pupillary 
block due to anterior displacement of the intracapsular 
IOL by vitreous gas.Case presentation
A 61-year-old Japanese female patient presented to our 
clinic with the chief complaint of persistent right-sided 
visual impairment over several months. At initial exami nation, her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/200 (right 
eye) and 20/20 (left eye), with an intraocular pressure 
(IOP) of 15 mmHg (exophthalmos) in both eyes. A slitlamp examination revealed a deep anterior chamber with 
a Van Herick grade of 3 or more, and moderate nuclear 
sclerosing cataracts were noted in both eyes. The axial 
length of the eye was 23.53 mm (right eye) and 24.05 mm 
(left eye).
No inflammation was observed in the eye. An examina tion of the anterior chamber showed: cell (−), flare (−), 
and keratic precipitate (−). The anterior chamber depth, 
measured using anterior segment optical coherence 
tomography (OCT), was 2.8 mm (right eye) and 2.77 mm 
(left eye) from the corneal epithelium and 2.25 mm (right 
eye) and 2.21  mm (left eye) from the corneal endothe lium. On the basis of slit lamp and anterior segment OCT 
findings, two ophthalmologists (ST, SN) deemed gonios copy unnecessary.
No glaucomatous optic nerve symptoms were noted in 
either eye, and a full-thickness stage 3 MH was identified 
in the right eye (Fig.  1A) during fundus examination. The 
patient had a history of surgery for spinal stenosis, per formed at an orthopedic clinic, but she did not have any 
history of systemic diseases such as diabetes or hyper tension, systemic inflammatory diseases, or diabetic 
retinopathy.
Fig. 1 Optical coherence tomography of the macular hole; A Initial presentation at our department showing a full-thickness macular hole, B Day 5 
post-simultaneous cataract surgery and the first 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy (PPV), demonstrating posterior vitreous detachment, implantation 
of a 3-piece 7-mm diameter monofocal intraocular lens, internal limiting membrane (ILM) peeling, and air tamponade; macular hole closure 
was not achieved, C A total of 2 weeks after the second 25-gauge pars plana vitrectomy with inverted internal limiting membrane flap and SF6 gas 
tamponade, closure of the macular hole was obtained
Page 3 of 6
 Takahashi et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:501 
 
Under local anesthesia (0.4% oxybuprocaine topical 
anesthesia and 0.75% ropivacaine transbulbar anesthe sia), the patient underwent simultaneous cataract surgery 
and PPV using the 25G Constellation Vitrectomy Sys tem (Alcon Laboratories, TX) and the RESIGHT Wide 
Angle Viewing System (Carl Zeiss Medec AG, Jena, TX). 
During the surgery, posterior vitreous detachment was 
induced and the internal limiting membrane was peeled. 
Then, a 3-piece acrylic monofocal intraocular lens (NX70S, Santen, Osaka, Japan) with a diameter of 7 mm and 
a power of +20.5 D was implanted. Subsequently, air 
tamponade was performed. No retinal tear was observed 
during surgery, thus endolaser was not required, and the 
surgery was completed without complications. Anesthe sia was performed using local anesthesia only, without 
the use of nitrous oxide.
After the first PPV, the patient was prescribed moxi floxacin hydrochloride four times daily, 0.1% betameth asone four times daily, 0.1% bromfenac twice daily, and 
tropicamide chloride ophthalmic drops once daily. Post operatively, the patient maintained the FDP without 
issues. However, owing to the non-closure of the MH 
(Fig.  1B), on postoperative day 13, the patient under went a second PPV with an internal limiting membrane 
inverted flap and SF6 gas tamponade. Postoperatively, the 
FDP was maintained. The following morning, the IOP 
was 5  mmHg, and the patient began using moxifloxa cin hydrochloride four times daily, 0.1% betamethasone four times daily, 0.1% bromfenac twice daily, and tropi camide chloride ophthalmic drops once daily. At 4 days 
post-second surgery, there were no indications of PSI to 
the remnant anterior capsule in the pseudophakic eye. 
IOP remained within the normal range at 10  mmHg, 
with approximately 70% of the gas still present in the 
vitreous cavity. At 6  days after the second surgery, the 
patient complained of ocular pain in the right eye and 
nausea. Iridodonesis was not observed. Anterior cham ber examination showed mild cells (±), no flare, and no 
keratic precipitates, indicating no significant inflamma tion. Slit-lamp examination revealed a shallow anterior 
chamber with a closed corner angle (Shaffer grade 0), a 
bulging iris, and pupillary block in the pseudophakic eye 
(Fig. 2A). The IOP was markedly elevated, at 53 mmHg.
Subsequently, the patient was diagnosed with ACG in 
the right eye with iris bombing. Treatment included sys temic treatment with 15% mannitol intravenously and 
250  mg acetazolamide hydrochloride orally, as well as a 
fixed combination of latanoprost-timolol (LATACHIMO 
NITTEN®, Nitten Co., Ltd., Japan), 0.1% brimonidine 
(Aiphagan®; Senju Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., Japan), 0.4% 
ripasudil (Glanatec®; Kowa Pharmaceuticals Co. Ltd, 
Japan), and 2% pilocarpine (Sanpilo®; Santen, Japan). 
However, no IOP reduction was observed; therefore, a 
laser peripheral iridotomy was performed on the right 
eye. Subsequently, the anterior chamber deepened, 
and the right IOP decreased to 7  mmHg the next day 
Fig. 2 Anterior segment optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT); A Anterior segment optical coherence tomography showed angle closure 
and iris bombe 6 days after the second pars plana vitrectomy, B Day 1 after laser iridotomy; anterior chamber deepened
Page 4 of 6 Takahashi et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:501 
(Fig.  2B). Thereafter, IOP was maintained within the nor mal range and the MH was closed (Fig. 1C).
Due to the poor visibility of the fundus caused by the 
SF6 gas, the exact timing of MH closure after the sec ond surgery remains unclear. However, MH closure was 
definitively confirmed on OCT performed at 8 days after 
the second surgery, with 40% of the SF6 gas still present. 
The best-corrected visual acuity at 1  month postopera tively was 20/100 (right eye), the anterior chamber was 
deep and stable, and the IOP was within normal limits at 
15 mm Hg.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
In this case, after initial vitrectomy, cataract surgery, and 
air tamponade failed to close the MH, a second vitrec tomy with SF6 gas tamponade was performed 2  weeks 
later, and 6 days post-second surgery, secondary AACG 
developed, likely due to PSI from repeated surgery or rel ative pupillary block caused by vitreous gas pushing the 
large-diameter IOL forward.
It is generally thought that relative pupillary block due 
to anterior movement of the IOL in pseudophakic eyes is 
rare. Additionally, there are no documented cases of rela tive pupillary block in pseudophakic eyes in the litera ture. In this instance, the patient had a pseudophakic eye 
with a large-diameter intracapsular IOL. However, in this 
case, the anterior movement of the intracapsular IOL due 
to the presence of vitreous SF6 gas could potentially have 
led to relative pupillary block.
A total of 2 days before the onset of AACG, which 
occurred 4  days after the second surgery, no PSI were 
detected during slit lamp examination. The IOP was 
within the normal range at 10  mmHg, with approxi mately 70% of the gas still present in the vitreous cav ity. However, it cannot be ruled out that PSI may have 
occurred in the 2 days preceding the AACG. Therefore, 
the causes of pupillary block in this case may have been 
PSI and/or relative pupillary block due to the anterior 
displacement of the large-diameter intracapsular IOL 
caused by the prolonged presence of vitreous gas. The 
use of a large-diameter IOL may have also contributed to 
the relative pupillary block.
FDP induces the anterior movement of the lens and 
enhances the effect of the relative pupillary block. Pro longed FDP has been previously cited as the cause of 
bilateral AACG. These cases occurred after FDP during 
spinal surgery in patients with no history of ophthalmic 
disease or surgery [12, 13]. Sutter et al. reported a case of 
AACG occurring in the fellow eye during FDP following 
PPV for retinal detachment [11]. This AACG occurred 
only in the fellow eye because the operated eye was pseu dophakic and the anterior chamber was deep, mitigating 
the rick of a pupillary block. Lee et  al. reported a case of bilateral AACG as a complication of FDP following 
MH surgery [14]. Although the operated eye had a gas 
tamponade, AACG occurred in both phakic eyes. The 
axial length of the eye with AACG was relatively short 
(22.79  mm [11] and 21.57  mm/21.50  mm [14]). How ever, in the present case, it is unlikely that AACG would 
occur through the same mechanism due to the patient’s 
pseudophakic eye. If AACG were to occur, it would be 
expected to affect both eyes, including the fellow phakic 
eye. Further, unlike cases reported previously [11, 14], the 
ocular axis in this current case was not short, measuring 
23.53 mm in the right eye and 24.05 mm in the left eye.
Angle closure secondary to PSI has rarely been reported 
after phacoemulsification. However, in a study examining 
anterior segment complications associated with com bined folding IOL insertion and phacoemulsification, 
pupillary block glaucoma (defined as an IOP > 24 mmHg) 
was observed in 4 out of 285 eyes [15]. Makhzhoum et al. 
reported a case of glaucoma caused by this mechanism 
5 years after the initial phacovitrectomy [7]. Czajka et al., 
in a study on the
sections.Results:
results of concomitant phacovitrec tomy, reported one case of elevated IOP (> 40  mmHg) 
attributed to PSI 2 weeks after the initial surgery [16]. In 
the series of ACG cases after phacovitrectomy reported 
by Raj et al., elevation of IOP requiring PI was observed 
between week 2 and week 8 [8]. This occurs when the PSI 
becomes firmly attached to the anterior capsular rim, 
leading to iris bombe formation, the earliness of which 
depends on several factors. The risk factors for PSI for mation are PDR, preoperative PSI, advanced-grade cata racts, gas tamponade or oil tamponade, single-piece IOL 
implantation, postoperative anterior chamber fibrin dep osition, presence of PDR, the extent of retinal photoco agulation, and duration of the operative procedure [6, 8, 
17–19]. The optics–haptics junction of single-piece IOLs 
is more susceptible to buoyancy from tamponade agents 
(gas/oil), leading to anterior protrusion of the IOL and 
subsequent adherence of the anterior capsule rim to the 
posterior iris surface [18]. Our case involved a gas tam ponade, along with a long FDP and surgery duration, 
considering the two-time surgeries. Furthermore, in this 
study, the AACG period after surgery was 20 days after 
the first PPV and 6 days after the second PPV, consistent 
with previous reports [8, 16].
As noted in several studies, gas or oil tamponade 
may increase PSI formation because the IOL adheres to 
the posterior surface of the iris [6, 20, 21]. In addition, 
patients with gas or silicone oil tamponade generally 
maintain a depressed or supine postoperative position, 
which may lead to an accumulation of growth factors in 
the anterior chamber and contribute to the formation of 
posterior synechiae. In this case, since the initial surgery 
did not involve closure, and stricter FDP was maintained 
Page 5 of 6
 Takahashi et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:501 
 
after the second surgery, which may have led to the accu mulation of growth factors in the anterior chamber and 
the formation of posterior synechiae. Although longer 
operative times may increase postoperative inflamma tion, potentially leading to PSI formation, the use of the 
25-gauge PPV in this study was anticipated to result in 
shorter operative times and less postoperative inflamma tion compared with the 20- and 23-gauge systems. How ever, considering that the reoperation was performed 
2 weeks after the initial surgery, the total operative time 
for the initial and second surgeries combined was longer 
compared with that typically associated with the stand ard 25-gauge system.
Both the fibrin membrane in the anterior chamber and 
PDR have been identified as risk factors for elevated IOP 
after intraocular surgery [22]. Fibrin exudation into the 
anterior chamber is significantly more common follow ing combined surgery, especially in cases of PDR [23]. Raj 
et  al. found that eyes with PDR are more likely to have 
an AACG [8]. Considering that this case was not a PDR, 
it is unusual for an AACG to have developed from a PSI. 
Therefore, although preemptive PI may be an option in 
cases prone to synechiae formation, especially in eyes 
filled with silicone oil and in cases of PDR, we did not 
perform prophylactic PI in this case because the risk of 
PSI and subsequent associated AACG was not consid ered to be high.
This case highlights a rare occurrence of secondary 
AACG in a pseudophakic eye following 25-gauge mini mally invasive PPV with SF6 gas tamponade for MH. The 
AACG was likely precipitated by PSI or relative pupil lary block caused by anterior movement of the IOL due 
to vitreous gas. The risk of secondary AACG persists in 
cases involving repeated surgeries for unclosed MHs, 
extended FDP , prolonged vitreous gas retention, or 
implantation of large-diameter IOLs. Notably, this risk 
extends to pseudophakic eyes, which are generally con sidered to have a low risk of relative pupillary block, and 
minimally invasive procedures such as 25-gauge PPV for 
MH repair, which is generally considered to have a low 
risk of PSI, not just highly invasive surgeries for PDR or 
vitreoretinopathy.
Abbreviations
AACG   Acute angle-closure glaucoma
IOP  Intraocular pressure
MH  Macular hole
PDR  Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
PPV  Pars plana vitrectomy

We thank Editage (www. edita ge. com) for English language editing.
Author contributions
All authors attest that they meet the current ICMJE criteria for authorship. ST 
collected the clinical data. SN collected, analyzed, and interpreted the clinical 
data and wrote the manuscript. ST, SN, and KI contributed to the design and conceptualization of this report. ST, SN, and KI made substantial contributions to the acquisition of the clinical data. All the authors have reviewed and 
approved the final version of the manuscript.
Funding
This study was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science 
(JSPS) KAKENHI, grant no. 19 K18837 (SN). The funding body played no role in 
the study design, collection, analysis, and interpretation of data, or manuscript 
writing.
Availability of data and materials
The datasets analyzed during the current study are available from the cor responding author upon reasonable request.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
The requirement for approval of this case report was waived by the Saitama 
Red Cross Hospital ethics committee owing to the retrospective nature of 
the study. All procedures conducted in this study adhered to the tenets of 
the Declaration of Helsinki. Written informed consent was obtained from the 
patient.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
